image.caption: An early design sketch by designer Bill Flajole shows basic small car concept for the Metropolitan.
The Metropolitan design, based on the big Nash, begins to come together in a later sketch by Flajole.
The first production Metropolitans had a distinctive floating single-bar grille reminiscent of the 1950 Americican.
With a wheelbase of just 85 inches, the Metropolitan was the smallest American car on the road.
By 1961 the Met had an oval mesh grille and the Nash/Hudson center medallion had been replace by a single red "M" on a black background.
Production ended on April 19, 1961. Over a year's supply of the little cars remained in stock and were sold as 1962 models. American Motors announced the end of the Metropolitan on March 23, 1962.
Although it never made it into production, Pinin Farina built one prototype Met wagon. It survives today in a small Metropolitan museum in North Hollywood, California.
Mets are a favorite subject for car illustrators, Life's a Met is an original watercolor by Rose Maloy (RM AUTO ART, PO box 179, Hershey PA 17033)
